I'm interested in getting into the discussion of fate and free will again, but, if it is okay with you Ooaman, I would like to place one restriction on the discussion. No discussion of causal determinism. I only say this because I've noticed that most discussions of fate, free will, Calvinism, etc. end up becominf discussions of causal determinism, and I'd just like to see it stay outside of there. It is a very complex discussion with a lot of elements and I don't think it is unreasonable to limit it so that it can take shape and not fly in a hundred directions.

 Well, fate could mean many different things. It could lay out your whole life for you, which seems to be what you're reffering to. Or it could just mean that a certain situation will arise, and how you handle it is up to you. For example, it could be your destiny to find a certain lost wallet. If you keep it, and go down one path, or return it, and go down another, is up to you.
 
 So here's a question. If fate exists, who sets it up? Are we saying that some supernatural entity is pulling the strings, or is it "simple" cause and effect traceable back to the big bang? Is everything that will ever happen, or at least every event that's "fated", already decided? Or does the influence of fate only appear at "close range"? If a certain event that occured to a certain person on Earth today was fated from the begining of time than alot (think Sagan's billions and billions here) of event would need to be preordained to make sure that it could even possibly come about.

It is always difficult to discuss fate because it isnt really provable one way or the other.

 So here's a question. If fate exists, who sets it up? Are we saying that some supernatural entity is pulling the strings, or is it "simple" cause and effect traceable back to the big bang? Is everything that will ever happen, or at least every event that's "fated", already decided? Or does the influence of fate only appear at "close range"?  i dont think destiny and free will can exist, except in the case of one "choosing his destiny" (which sounds like an oxymoron). if you are destined to end up at C, then it would not be possible to end up at C1, even if the option to end up at C1 became available at some point. because if from B you arrived at C1 instead of C, then your destiny could not have been to end up at C, and vice versa.
 
 discussions about destiny can only occur in hindsight. "it happened, must have been destiny". a destiny implies a point C that you havent arrived at yet. it makes no sense to recognise that C was your destiny after the fact that youve already arrived at C

 I question the premise that you can make a completely random choice. All choices are inherently limited by various factors: your environment, your knowledge, your skills, etc. Now, once the choices are restricted, I don't know that you truly can (or if possible, that anyone does) make a random choice. You always have reasons behind your choices whether they are good ones or not. And if you do, that choice cannot be random.
 
 Now, lets say you were hungry for some fruit. In your house you had an apple, and orange, and a banana. You can't decide which one you want, so you put the names of each piece of fruit on a piece of paper and choose one out of a hat. This is the only kind of thing I can think of that has the slightest semblance of being random, but even so, it is not truly random. Your choices were what they were because you hadn't bought pears or grapes at your last trip to the grocery store and by the fact that you hadn't eaten all of the bananas yet.

 Maybe I'm thinking on a different definition than everyone else when I say "random." Have you ever heard of the phrase "when one door closes, another one opens?" This is where my terminology of A comes in. There is one door that closes. But you have 35 other proverbial doors that are open to you. You have to choose one but you have a choice of one out of 35. With 35 of those proverbial doors that you can choose from, you wind up going into door #21. Your reason for choosing door #21 was for no other reason than because it was one that was available. You don't know what to expect from #21 anymore than you would know what to expect from #17 or #32 or #9. But the door you went into is #21. Then later along the line you wind up with the C. But granted, everyone probably has a different definition of random than I do. But this is what I meant when I say randomly chose the A. Now when you find C, is that fate or chance/coincidence?

i've alwase considered the differance between determanism and fate to be that fate is a mystical idea that there is some uknowable set path for the future to unvold in, while determanism is based uppon the idea that any given person's actions are theoreticaly predictable, if you know what all of the influences on that person are.
 
 if it is to be considerted theoreticaly possible to predict the actions a somebody based on all of the infulences on that person, then all of those influences must exist before action is taken. In the example given of the apartment complex - the beliver in determanism belives that the apartment that is chosen will depend upon something pre-existing and predictable. i would imagen that in the case of this apartment complex, certan things would be considered - what floor the room is on, whether it is near the stairs, that sort of thing. supposing all of those things are considered and there are still several identical options remaing then the determanist claims it is still theoreticaly possible to know beforhand what sort of person this is, that is makeing the desition, do they have a favorate number? are they the type to just choose the first untaken number, or the highest, or was there some subconcious influences experanced prior to their choosing that lead them to say "eh, twenty... one." It is fair for the determanist to claim that even if a person makes a desition just based on what they want or what sort of person they are, then those things are still predictable, and have influences of their own that made them what they are.
 
 i dont buy it, because creativity denys predicatbilty. Creativity is the force by witch people create ideas, and thus it is an important factor in desition makeing. And it is not predictable - it denys predictablity. to illustrate this point, consider the interaction of creativity to mathematics - witch is an otherwise knowable and predictable system. for example, the number pi comes from the creative idea to mesure the circumfrance of a circle, by seeing how many times the diamiter of a circle could wrap around the outside of a circle. the result is a number witch can not be fully calculated because its next number can not be predicted. Or, try arrangeing differant numbers of things into a square, and you will be able to do it sometims, but not other times, when you can and cant do it is predictable, because a square is a mathematical idea - a thing with four equaly distant sides, it can be described in terms of numbers. also you can arrange any number of rocks into a rectangle, if you include a rectangle that is just one rock high or wide, but if you have the creative idea to limit the shape you wish to create to a rectangle that is at least two rocks high or wide, then the instances when you wont be able to do it becoem totaly unpredictable (prime numbers)

 Okay, you keep saying that in order for something to be even close to being completely random, it has to be chosen in a drawing type situation by you. Let's say there is something you want like a car. But you're not the only one who wants it. 35,000 other people want it also. Everyone puts their name in a bowl to be selected to win the car (or whatever said object.) You have a possibility of 1/35,001 of getting that said object. (35,001 is because there are 35,000 besides you and so you make one more. Just wanted to clear that up. A debate on my math calculations can be saved for the Science and Math debate forum.) The host of the event reaches into the bowl after a set amount of time. Now if you win, there was nothing else you could have done but put your name in. The same goes for the other 35,000 hopefuls. Provided that the host isn't related to anyone or isn't trying to impress someone who put their names in the bowl or hasn't somehow fixed the drawing to allow them to come out, will the selection be totally at random?

It is a combination of your own action and outside factors (actions or events you are not in control of) that results in something that some call fate and others coincidence or chance. that is my answer to you question.

Can I get any more opinions on this? The question is of Fate vs. Chance/Coincidence. I will go a head and say that I prefer to believe it's Fate. Like it was meant to happen.  theres is actually no difference between fate, chance, coincidence, destiny, etc. they are all terms people use to describe the same thing. if i mix a cake batter and put it in the oven for a certain amount of time, ill get cake. this is neither fate, destiny, coincidence or chance, but simply the result of actions i carried out. of course, you could call it fate, destiny, coicidence or chance. what you call it simply indicates your perspective on the world around you. even an unexpected result is a result of actions that took place, probably partially or wholly on your part, but the fact that you didnt expect the result doesnt mean its anything less than the effects of those actions.

Or even better than the first idea, it's better than cake, gets pattent, put in Betty Crocker's Cook Book and you become a multi-millionaire for your not-but-better cake.
 I expanded on this because I don't really see how the cake getting baked when you decide to bake a cake is either fate or chance or coincidence. (Though if I were to bake a cake and it came out as a cake that didn't kill anyone, I would personally call that good luck, but not fate.)
 For example, I did my laundry today, but it wasn't fate that my cloths came out clean.

 this would be a result of you accidentally making the cake differently from how cake is normally made. you either added more of something, left out something, baked it at a different temperature, etc. regardless, the great-tasting i-cant-believe-its-not-cake that you made is a result of the actions you carried out.
 
 lets say you make a mix of random ingredients, and it comes out to be a great product, youd call that fate, right? what if you did it again, used the exact same ingredients and the exact method, but only this time you actually know what to expect, and lo and behold it turns out to be that great product again, was the second time fate? what about the third and 50th times? is an action only fate if the result is unexpected by us?

 However anyone feels it is, this wasn't really what I had in mind with the original question. My original question was based upon something working out one way or another after an at least some what random decision on your part or a somewhat random choosing on your part or someone elses part. Saying that a person baking a cake is random sounds like a joke of no internal monologue...
 Person 1: We have a crises on our hands.
 Person 2: I think I'll bake a cake.
 Person 1: What?emoticon_confused
 The only actual random choosing would be what kind of cake (Angel food, Devil's food, lemon cake, sponge cake, pound cake, pineapple upsidedown cake ect.) or the choice to or not to put frosting on. Or maybe the random choice was made by the Betty Crocker connection who randomly showed up. But the idea of "well, I went in to bake a cake and guess what, I got a cake! It must have been fate that I got a cake," isn't what I'm referring to.
The point is, whatever the result is. it is the product of your own choices and other factors that you don't have control over. If you made a semi-random choice, you will have a semi-random result.

The point is, whatever the result is. it is the product of your own choices and other factors that you don't have control over. If you made a semi-random choice, you will have a semi-random result.

 And if you mix it together (the result of your semi-random choice combined with the result of that beyond your power) you get what you've already said is pure chance or coincidence. I would either call it fate or glorified coincidence (which I'm starting to think I'll call it.) But the cake example that unkerpaulie gave wasn't a random choice combined with stuff beyond someone's power; unless, like me, they don't have the slightest idea how to bake a cake.
The only difference between chance and "glorified coincidence" is how much....well....glory you put into it. The meaning is essentially the same.

Ok, here's something entirely different. Try to wrap your minds around it just a bit before attacking the messenger, please? This will all be common 'world-view' in a couple hundred years.
 
 'Existence' is made of 'moments'. These are Planck moments, 'timeless' in their 'duration', as they are too 'quick' to qualify as 'time' (an 'illusion').
 
 The difference is that all 'moments', although 'appearing' to be sequential, leading to the eroneous perception/conception of a linear temporal paradigm, are not sequential but mutually arrisen simultaneously. All 'moments' of 'existence', 'ever', are Here/Now. All at once; more like a magnificent tapestry than one 'moment' turning into another, 'causing and effecting' all over the place. 'Even the terms 'cause and effect' have become obsolete. Cause and effect are now considered to be 'mutually arrising aspects of the same 'event''. Ordering the moments are arbitrary and fallacious.
 
 As all 'moments' of existence are already a 'done deal', as there is no 'motion', nothing turning into something else, no 'decisions' of what to 'do' or which way to 'go' (as there is no 'doing' or 'going')... all concepts of 'free-will' and 'freedom' itself are vain ego delusions. The vanity of the ego imagining a 'self' that is 'in charge' of 'things', 'doing', 'choosing'... 
 Vanity, vanity. 
 
 As we are dealing with 'egos' there will be 'knee-jerk' reactions to defend/attack to preserve and inflate the delusions that the ego feeds upon. Please try to understand the 'material' before 'killing the messenger'. Understanding does not mean that you must accept. 
 
 Actually, you have no choice in the matter.
 
 Some food for thought might be derived HERE and HERE from Benjamin Libet regarding 'choice to act' and 'action', actual experimental 'evidence' to ponder.
 
 Another site that might be interesting is God Has No Free-Will.
